Name: Book of Enoch
Metaphysical Tags: Becoming (Process Ontology), Clockwork (Causal Determinism), Subversion (Negation), Monism (Single Principle)
Arts and Sciences Tags: Philosophy, History, Anthropology, Astronomy, Education, Political Science / Law
Short Description: An ancient apocalyptic and pseudepigraphal work, traditionally attributed to Enoch, the great-grandfather of Noah. It is structured in five sections: the Book of Watchers (on fallen angels), the Book of Parables (on divine judgment), the Astronomical Book (a solar calendar and cosmology), the Dream Visions (symbolic history), and the Epistle of Enoch (ethical exhortations and prophecy). Composed originally in Aramaic and later preserved in Geʽez (Ethiopic), the text reflects a mix of Yahwistic, apocalyptic, and priestly traditions. It was highly influential in Second Temple Judaism and early Christianity, shaping ideas of angels, resurrection, and final judgment. Though excluded from most biblical canons, it remained canonical in the Ethiopian Orthodox Church and offers rare insight into pre-rabbinic Jewish thought.

Name: Ben Sira (Sirach / Ecclesiasticus)
Metaphysical Tags: Phenomenology (Experiential), Clockwork (Causal Determinism), Monism (Single Principle), Becoming (Process Ontology), Grid (Systematic Structuralism)
Short Description: This Jewish wisdom text offers ethical teachings on piety, humility, social behavior, and reverence for the Law, combining traditional Jewish values with Hellenistic literary form. The text praises wisdom as divine and highlights the moral responsibilities of individuals in family and society. A notable section (chapters 44–50) offers poetic praise of biblical heroes, linking ethical instruction to communal memory. Around 132 BCE, Ben Sira’s grandson translated the work into Greek while living in Egypt, enabling its inclusion in the Septuagint. Though excluded from the Jewish rabbinic canon, it was later adopted into Christian Bibles as deuterocanonical by Catholic and Orthodox traditions.

Name: Dead Sea Scrolls (early layer)
Metaphysical Tags: Apophatic–Aporetic (Unknowable), Monism (Single Principle), Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Subversion (Negation)
Arts and Sciences Tags: Political Science / Law, Education, History, Philosophy
Short Description: A collection of biblical manuscripts, apocalyptic writings, and sectarian rules composed by a dissident Jewish community, likely the Yahad or Essenes. These texts reinterpret Hebrew Bible stories through a lens of divine election, ritual purity, and imminent cosmic judgment, portraying their authors as the true remnant of Israel. The writers were not hired scribes but voluntarily ascetic, priestly dissidents, who retreated to the desert in protest against what they saw as the corrupt Temple elite. They lived communally under strict rules, viewing themselves as participants in a sacred drama unfolding at the end of time. The texts are a radical expression of Yahwistic monotheism, shaped by prophetic tradition, apocalyptic urgency, and sectarian withdrawal.

Name: Book of Jubilees
Metaphysical Tags: Becoming (Process Ontology), Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Clockwork (Causal Determinism), Monism (Single Principle), Subversion (Negation)
Arts and Sciences Tags: History, Philosophy, Political Science / Law, Education
Short Description: A Yahwistic Hebrew priestly-compendium that retells Genesis and early Exodus in a strict framework of 49-year jubilee cycles. Cast as a revelation to Moses through the angel of the presence, it projects Mosaic law—Sabbath, circumcision, festivals, purity—back onto the patriarchs, making Israel’s covenantal practices appear eternal and universal. Its distinctive 364-day solar calendar imposes cosmic order on history and separates its adherents from the lunar calendar of the Jerusalem temple. Politically, Jubilees is one of the first Yahwistic texts to explicitly merge sacred law with a nationalist program: Israelites are portrayed as chosen people whose survival depends on strict observance of divine law, separation from Gentiles, and possession of the promised land. Written when Judea lay squeezed between the great Hellenistic empires (Seleucids to the north, Ptolemies to the south), it offered a theological blueprint for resisting assimilation and legitimizing Hasmonean sovereignty.

Name: Testament of the Twelve Patriarchs
Metaphysical Tags: Becoming (Process Ontology), Pluralism (Multiplicities), Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Apophatic–Aporetic (Unknowable), Monism (Single Principle)
Arts and Sciences Tags: Education, Political Science / Law, History, Philosophy
Short Description: This pseudepigraphical work presents the deathbed speeches of Jacob’s twelve sons, each delivering autobiographical confession, ethical instruction, and prophetic vision to their descendants. Written originally in a Jewish context, the text reflects Yahwistic covenant theology, Second Temple apocalypticism, and tribal moral archetypes, especially emphasizing Levitical priesthood and Davidic kingship. The Text serves as a moral-prophetic guidebook for Israel's future, framed within a mythic-historical structure.

Name: 2 Maccabees
Metaphysical Tags: Dialectics (Conflict), Becoming (Process Ontology), Pluralism (Multiplicities), Subversion (Negation), Grid (Systematic Structuralism)
Arts and Sciences Tags: Education, Political Science / Law, History, Philosophy
Short Description: 2 Maccabees is a Greek abridgment of Jason of Cyrene’s lost five-volume history. Unlike 1 Maccabees’ political chronicle, it retells the Antiochene persecutions and the rise of Judas Maccabeus with a theological and sermonic focus. The text emphasizes martyrdom, resurrection hope, divine justice, and the sanctity of the Temple, presenting history as God’s intervention in defense of the faithful. Its intent was to strengthen Jewish identity under foreign rule and to frame the revolt as a sacred struggle rather than a purely military one. It survives only in Greek, preserved within the Septuagint, later becoming canonical in Catholic and Orthodox traditions but excluded from the Hebrew Bible.

Name: 1 Maccabees
Metaphysical Tags: Dialectics (Conflict), Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Clockwork (Causal Determinism), Subversion (Negation)
Arts and Sciences Tags: Warfare, Political Science / Law, Education, History
Short Description: A historical narrative written in Judea, originally composed in Hebrew but surviving only through its Greek translation in the Septuagint. It recounts the revolt of the Jewish priestly family, the Hasmoneans (or Maccabees), against Seleucid rule in the 2nd century BCE. The text details the desecration of the Jerusalem Temple, the rise of Judas Maccabeus and his brothers, their guerrilla campaigns, battles for religious freedom, and the eventual rededication of the Temple (commemorated in Hanukkah). It emphasizes covenantal fidelity, divine providence through human leadership, and the legitimacy of Hasmonean rule, blending religious and political history. Though central to understanding Jewish resistance, it was excluded from the Hebrew Bible—likely because the Hasmonean dynasty later fell into disrepute and the book’s dynastic legitimation no longer served Rabbinic priorities.

Name: Psalms of Solomon
Metaphysical Tags: Dialectics (Conflict), Becoming (Process Ontology), Grid (Systematic Structuralism), Subversion (Negation), Pluralism (Multiplicities)
Arts and Sciences Tags: Political Science / Law, Education, History, Philosophy
Short Description: A collection of 18 psalms written in Judea in the aftermath of the Roman general Pompey’s conquest of Jerusalem in 63 BCE. The text laments the corruption of Hasmonean rulers, interprets foreign domination as divine punishment, and looks forward to a righteous Davidic Messiah who will restore Israel. Its tone blends penitential prayer, national lament, and messianic hope, marking it as both political critique and theological reflection. Originally composed in Hebrew, the work survives mainly through Greek manuscripts and later Syriac and other translations. Preserved outside the Hebrew Bible, it circulated within Jewish sectarian groups and later Christian circles, remaining a powerful witness to late Second Temple messianic expectation.
